issues.description: The solution implementation declares the Lecture attributes using snake_case names (e.g. lecture_name, number_of_inscribed_students) but the constructor, getters, setters and other methods use camelCase identifiers (e.g. lectureName, numberOfInscribedStudents). This mismatch will cause compilation errors in the solution repository and is inconsistent with the UML / attribute names in the problem statement (which use camelCase). Because the template expects students to add attributes with the UML names, the solution should use the same attribute identifiers — the current inconsistent naming in the solution is an unintentional structural bug that would confuse students and prevent using the solution as a correct reference.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the attribute identifiers in the solution match the names from the UML/problem statement and the identifiers used in the methods. Concretely, rename the private fields to camelCase (lectureName, numberOfInscribedStudents, numberOfGuestStudents, numberOfLecturers, numberOfTutors) OR consistently change all constructor parameters and all method references to the declared snake_case fields. Prefer using the camelCase names to match the problem statement and Java naming conventions so students can follow the example without syntax errors.

issues.description: The problem statement (UML and text) defines the Lecture attributes using camelCase names (lectureName, numberOfInscribedStudents, numberOfGuestStudents, numberOfLecturers, numberOfTutors). In the solution implementation the attributes are declared using snake_case (lecture_name, number_of_inscribed_students, number_of_guest_students, number_of_lecturers, number_of_tutors) while the rest of the solution (constructor, getters/setters and methods) uses the camelCase identifiers (lectureName, numberOfInscribedStudents, ...). This mismatch between the attribute declarations and the identifiers used elsewhere (and between the solution and the problem statement UML) creates a direct naming inconsistency that will confuse students mapping the UML to code and leads to an implementation that does not compile as-is.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the attribute names in the solution match the camelCase identifiers used in the problem statement and throughout the solution. For example, rename the declared fields in solution_repository/src/de/tum/cit/ase/Lecture.java to: private String lectureName; private int numberOfInscribedStudents; private int numberOfGuestStudents; private int numberOfLecturers; private int numberOfTutors; This ensures consistent naming across UML, template, and solution and avoids compilation and mapping confusion.
